ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: none
N/a
live virtual presentations

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learnt how to develop better arguments for academic writing, and how to manage nuanced and complex claims throughout my papers.
Reading and analyzing text, writing academic papers
Editing, and essay form skills.

More generally, I was able to hone my skills and confidence as a writer. But, more broadly, I was able to better facilitate meaningful research, and learn to draw from supporting resources to enrich my papers.
I learned about writing college-level essays with a focus on research as well as on specific pieces of academic literature. I became a more confident writer by taking this course.
I learned how to write an effective argument and developed immensely as a writer.

This course not only improved the overall quality of my writing but also introduced ways of structuring my thoughts in a cohesive essay. Insights learned throughout the course allowed me to analyze the writings from a different perspective. I believe this course was crucial to crafting my personal style as a writer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought Memento was a great movie to analyze for this course! The readings were also interesting despite their convoluted writing style (I grew to appreciate Hayden and White). The ENGL 114 schedule for paper due dates / revision could be improved -- I think I would have benefitted from iterations of paper revision, starting from the first paper.
I cannot think of any improvements for this class.

A huge strength of this course was the opportunity to dive into creative topics. Students had a lot of freedom in their interpretation of the works we read and our class discussions were very engaging.
Professor Eklund made each class a lot of fun and very interesting. There aren't any obvious weaknesses with the course that I can think of.

To be honest, there were no obvious weaknesses. Despite the remote mode of learning, this course managed to keep the same level of engagement. The flexible philosophy of the professor about the deadlines promoted the environment in which students focus on improvement rather than meeting the requirements.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live zoom seminar format of this course worked wonderfully given the COVID-19 pandemic. However, students may benefit from externally collaborating on their own as they write and peer-review their papers. This external collaboration could be facilitated and encouraged in the class, or organized by the students independently.
Small section and seminar format made the course more engaging
Live discussions were an effective form of instruction for this course.

In comparison to other courses, this one succeeded in creating the most comfortable environment for learning during the pandemic. The discussions still felt lively despite being held over zoom. There was no awkward silence following a question asked by the professor. The professor himself often started the conversation to lead into the discussion, which I found very effective. 
The group work also didn't lag behind because private rooms and shared google documents worked out pretty well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! My writing improved tremendously throughout the semester, all thanks to how engaged Craig was with each paper. The material we encountered was extremely compelling as well, especially all the texts concerning narrative psychology.
Absolutely. I learned a lot from the professor and my colleagues and really improved my writing and editing skills.
Yes! The course material was super interesting and the course as a whole was very helpful in improving the quality, complexity, and organization of my writing.
Yes, I strongly recommend this course to other students, especially to those who want to improve their writing skills to the level required by Yale.

I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Eklund was amazing and I always looked forward to his class. The class itself was engaging and the feedback we received certainly made me a better writer.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. The professor is eager to help and get in touch with students at any time. The variety of topics covered in the course is impressive. It perfectly balances academic rigor and a friendly environment for development. The topics of discussion weren't limited to the writings, but films also took a fair amount of time.
